prior_works.title: Restless bandits: Activity allocation in a changing world
prior_works.role: Foundational RMAB formulation and Lagrangian relaxation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s SP-based policy builds on Whittle’s Lagrangian decoupling of multi-project RMABs, providing the structural relaxation that enables per-arm stochastic approximations and tractable large-N analysis.

prior_works.title: Restless Bandits, Linear Programming Relaxations, and a Near-Optimal Policy
prior_works.role: LP-relaxation and fluid-approximation based control for RMABs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work established LP-based (fluid) relaxations and policies for RMABs that the present paper explicitly improves upon by incorporating variance via a Gaussian approximation to overcome degeneracy-driven 1/√N gaps.

prior_works.title: On an index policy for restless bandits
prior_works.role: Asymptotic analysis for many-arm RMABs and mean-field style decoupling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Weber–Weiss’s large-system viewpoint motivates the homogeneous, large-N regime and the idea that asymptotically derived policies can be near-optimal, a premise extended here from fluid to Gaussian approximations.

prior_works.title: Limit theorems for density dependent Markov chains
prior_works.role: Fluid (LLN) and diffusion (CLT) approximations for large stochastic systems
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Kurtz’s LLN/CLT framework directly underpins the paper’s replacement of fluid limits with a Gaussian system capturing both mean and variance of the RMAB occupancy dynamics.

prior_works.title: Brownian Motion and Stochastic Flow Systems
prior_works.role: Brownian/diffusion models and control (Brownian control problems)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Harrison’s diffusion-control paradigm informs the paper’s key step of optimizing a Gaussian (diffusion) surrogate to synthesize implementable policies with tighter ˜O(1/N) gaps.

prior_works.title: Stochastic Programming
prior_works.role: Foundations of stochastic programming, especially with Gaussian uncertainty
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s stochastic-programming formulation over a Gaussian system leverages classic tractability and reformulations from Prékopa’s framework for chance constraints and moment-based Gaussian programs.

prior_works.title: A mean field approach for optimization in Markov decision processes with large populations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Mean-field MDP methods by Gast–Gaujal provide the fluid-control baseline and uniqueness-style assumptions that the paper refines by adding variance-aware (Gaussian) corrections to handle degeneracy.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core advance—achieving a ˜O(1/N) optimality gap for degenerate homogeneous RMABs—sits at the intersection of RMAB relaxations and diffusion-based stochastic control. Whittle’s formulation of restless bandits and Lagrangian decoupling supplies the structural backbone enabling tractable per-arm analysis. Building on this, LP-based relaxations and fluid policies from Bertsimas and Niño-Mora established a powerful baseline that performs excellently under non-degeneracy, yet can stall at Θ(1/√N) gaps when degeneracies arise. The large-population, asymptotic perspective of Weber and Weiss motivates the homogeneous, many-arm setting where approximation-driven policies can be provably near-optimal.

Methodologically, the paper’s decisive step is to move beyond the fluid (LLN) approximation to a Gaussian (CLT/diffusion) approximation. Kurtz’s limit theorems justify modeling occupancy fluctuations around the fluid trajectory as Gaussian, while Harrison’s Brownian control program suggests that optimizing a diffusion surrogate can yield implementable policies with sharper performance guarantees. To operationalize this, the authors formulate and solve a stochastic program defined on the Gaussian system; Prékopa’s stochastic programming foundations—particularly for Gaussian uncertainties—inform tractable reformulations and solution strategies. Finally, mean-field control insights from Gast and Gaujal clarify when fluid solutions are unique and how variance-aware corrections can systematically repair fluid-level degeneracies. Together, these strands directly enable the paper’s SP-based Gaussian policy and its improved ˜O(1/N) gap in regimes where LP/fluid methods are insufficient.
